ygData.subject: Re: Source Code For Jeff Clune's HyperNEAT Experiments (through July 2010)

Hey Jeff,

Thanks for releasing the code, I think that the community will b=
enefit from having access to as many experiments as possible.

I'll work on=
 merging the code with the existing HyperNEAT code.  I recently went throug=
h the code and made a 15x improvement on the performance, so I will take th=
e changes I made and your experiments and release a version 3.1.

Jason G.
=

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>
> Hello all-=

> 
> Some of you have asked for the source code of my HyperNEAT experiment=
s (so
> far).
> 
> I kept putting off publishing the code until I had time =
to clean up the
> code. Instead of further delay, I am just releasing it as=
 is.
> 
> Here is a link to it:
> 
> http://tinyurl.com/JeffCluneHyperNEATc=
ode
> 
> The most requested code--that for evolving gaits for simulated qua=
druped
> robots--is in here as the LegSwingExperiment. There is a readme fi=
le for how
> to get started. If you have any questions, just let me know.
>=
 
> PS. I think it would be fun to have the robot experiment included in th=
e
> more canonical HyperNEAT releases, if the maintainers of those packages=
 are
> interested. It is very fun to watch the robots evolve, and it quickl=
y gives
> one a sense of the difference in behaviors produced by HyperNEAT =
vs. NEAT
> and FT-NEAT. I have found that being able to download a package =
and see
> something that is visually intuitive can often engage an enthusia=
st/hobbyist
> who does not immediately know how to evaluate improved perfor=
mance on more
> abstract problems (e.g. the boxes domain). So, it would be =
nice to have
> something like this for them to immediately see and play wit=
h. Just a
> thought. 
> 
> Best regards,
> Jeff Clune
> 
> Digital Evolutio=
n Lab, Michigan State University
> jclune@...
> www.msu.edu/~jclune
>
